Intro to DPO

Preference tuning is a common step in fine-tuning Language Models, where the model learns to favor desirable responses over less helpful ones.

A popular approach for this is Direct Preference Optimization (DPO). It trains models on examples like: Prompt; chosen response; rejected response

Compared to other Preference Tuning methods like Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (e.g. PPO), DPO has several advantages:

‚úÖ Simplicity

‚úÖ Stability

‚úÖ Memory efficiency

DPO is popular among practitioners, and not only: even Llama-3 was trained with DPO.

DPO limitations

‚ùå Research has shown that DPO often falls short of PPO in terms of model performance (see Is DPO Superior to PPO for LLM Alignment? A Comprehensive Study).

One common critique is that DPO often uses only off-policy data‚Äîdata generated by models other than the one being trained. This can introduce distribution shifts during training, which may impact performance.

However, this isn‚Äôt a limitation of DPO itself, but just a common practice.

üíé We can overcome this limit by using on-policy data: data generated by the model being trained.

How to create an on-policy dataset for DPO

  1. Select a source of prompts (ideally different from data used to previously train the model).
  2. Sample the original model to generate 2 (or more) responses üé≤.
  3. Evaluate and rank the responses with a Reward Model or LLM as a Judge üßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è.

In fact, the T√úLU 3 technical report shows that combining off-policy + on-policy data gives better performance compared to off-policy data alone.
